verses.verse: (1 Job complaineth, and curseth the day of his birth. 11 He desireth to die, as though death were the end of all man’s misery.) Afterward (The seven days ended, Job 2:13.) Job opened his mouth, and (Here Job beginneth to feel his great imperfection in this battle between the spirit and the flesh, Rom. 7:18, and after a manner yieldeth, yet in the end he getteth victory, though he was in the mean time greatly wounded.) cursed his day.
And Job cried out, and said,

Let the day (Men ought not to be weary of their life, and curse it, because of the infirmities that it is subject unto, but because they are given to sin and rebellion against God.) perish wherein I was born, and the night when it was said, There is a man child conceived.

Let that day be darkness, let not God (Let it be put out of the number of days, and let it not have the light of the Sun to separate it from the night.) regard it from above, neither let the light shine upon it,

But let darkness and the (That is, most obscure darkness, which maketh them afraid of death that are in it.) shadow of death stain it: let the cloud remain upon it, and let them make it fearful as a bitter day.
Let darkness possess that night, let it not be joined unto the days of the year, nor let it come into the count of the months.
Yea, desolate be that night, and let no joy be in it.
Let them that curse the day, (being (Which curse the day of their birth, let them lay that curse upon this night.) ready to renew their mourning) curse it.

Let the stars of that twilight be dim through darkness of it: let it look for light, but have none: neither let it (Let it be always night, and never see day.) see (Hebrew, The eyelids of the morning.) the dawning of the day,
Because it shut not up the doors of my mother’s womb, nor hid sorrow from mine eyes.

(This, and that which followeth, declareth, that when man giveth place to his passions, he is not able to stay nor keep measure, but runneth headlong into all evil, except God call him back.) Why died I not in the birth? or why died I not, when I came out of the womb?
Why did the knees prevent me? and why did I suck the breasts?

For so should I now have (The vehemency of his afflictions made him to utter these words, as though death were the end of all miseries, and as if there were no life after this, which he speaketh not as though it were so, but the infirmities of his flesh caused him to burst out in this error of the wicked.) lain and been quiet, I should have slept then, and been at rest,

With the kings and counselors of the earth, which have built themselves (He noteth the ambition of them, which for their pleasure as it were change the order of nature, and build in most barren places, because they would hereby make their names immortal.) desolate places:
Or with the princes that had gold, and have filled their houses with silver.
Or why was I not hid, as an untimely birth, either as infants, which have not seen the light?
The wicked (That is, by death the cruelty of the tyrants hath ceased.) have there ceased from their tyranny, and there they that labored valiantly, are at rest.
The (All they that sustain any kind of calamity and misery in this world: which he speaketh after the judgment of the flesh.) prisoners rest together, and hear not the voice of the oppressor.
There are small and great, and the servant is free from his master.

Wherefore is the light given to him that is in misery? and (He showeth that the benefits of God are not comfortable, expect the heart be joyful, and the conscience quieted.) life unto them that have heavy hearts?
Which long for death, and if it come not, they would even search it more than treasures:
Which joy for gladness, and rejoice, when they can find the grave.
Why is the light given to the man whose way is (That seeth not how to come out of his miseries, because he dependeth not on God’s providence.) hid, and whom God hath hedged in?
For my sighing cometh before I eat, and my roarings are poured out like the water.
For the thing I (In my prosperity I looked ever for a fall, as is come now to pass.) feared, is come upon me, and the thing that I was afraid of, is come unto me.

I had no peace, neither had I quietness, neither had I rest, (The fear of troubles that should ensue, caused my prosperity to seem to me as nothing, and yet I am not exempted from trouble.) yet trouble is come.
